questions.text: Which of the following is a primary physical barrier in the innate immune system?
questions.solution:
The skin acts as a primary physical barrier to pathogens, preventing their entry into the body. It is one of the first lines of defense in the innate immune system. Other options like macrophages, neutrophils, and complement proteins are part of the innate immune response but not physical barriers.

Key Takeaway: The skin is a crucial physical barrier that helps protect against infections by blocking pathogen entry.

questions.text: Which innate immune component is responsible for recognizing and binding to pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs)?
questions.solution:
Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a type of pattern recognition receptor that recognizes and binds to pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) on pathogens. This recognition helps initiate the immune response. B cells and T cells are part of the adaptive immune system, while NK cells are involved in killing infected or cancerous cells, not in recognizing PAMPs.

Key Takeaway: TLRs play a critical role in the innate immune system by detecting and responding to pathogens through PAMP recognition.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key feature of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
• Immediate response to pathogens: Innate immunity provides a rapid, non-specific response to infections and is the first line of defense.
  • Specific recognition of antigens: This is characteristic of acquired (adaptive) immunity, not innate immunity.
  • Development of memory cells: Memory cell development is a feature of acquired immunity.
  • Production of antibodies: Antibody production is primarily a function of acquired immunity.

Key Takeaway: The innate immune system is known for its immediate and non-specific response to pathogens.

questions.text: Which type of immunity involves the production of antibodies by B cells in response to a specific pathogen?
questions.solution:
• Humoral Immunity: This type of acquired immunity involves B cells producing antibodies that specifically target pathogens.
  • Cellular Immunity: Involves T cells and does not primarily focus on antibody production but on killing infected cells and regulating immune responses.
  • Innate Immunity: Involves general, non-specific responses and does not involve specific antibody production.
  • Passive Immunity: Involves the transfer of antibodies from one individual to another and does not involve the recipient’s own B cell response.

Key Takeaway: Humoral immunity is responsible for the production of antibodies by B cells to combat specific pathogens.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with symptoms of joint pain, fatigue, and a positive anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) test. Which of the following autoantibodies is most commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)?
questions.solution:
• Anti-dsDNA: Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and are often associated with renal involvement in the disease. They are a key diagnostic marker for SLE.
  • Anti-SSA: These antibodies are primarily associated with Sjögren's syndrome and can also appear in SLE but are less specific.
  • Anti-CCP: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies are specific for rheumatoid arthritis, not SLE.
  • Anti-Scl-70: These antibodies are associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), not SLE.

Key Takeaway: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are a key marker in diagnosing and managing SLE.

questions.text: In a patient with rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following laboratory findings is most characteristic?
questions.solution:
• High levels of anti-dsDNA: These are associated with SLE, not rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Elevated anti-CCP antibodies: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies are specific for rheumatoid arthritis and are often elevated in this condition.
  • Positive anti-Scl-70: These antibodies are associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), not rheumatoid arthritis.
  • High levels of anti-SSA: These antibodies are linked with Sjögren's syndrome and SLE but not rheumatoid arthritis.

Key Takeaway: Elevated anti-CCP antibodies are a key diagnostic marker for rheumatoid arthritis.

choices.text: T cell-mediated destruction of beta cells
Formation of immune complexes in the skin
Production of autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors

questions.text: A patient with Hashimoto's thyroiditis presents with elevated levels of anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies. What is the primary autoimmune mechanism in Hashimoto's thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
• Autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid cells: Hashimoto's thyroiditis involves autoantibodies against thyroid peroxidase (TPO) leading to the destruction of thyroid cells, causing hypothyroidism.
  • T cell-mediated destruction of beta cells: This mechanism is characteristic of Type 1 diabetes, not Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • Formation of immune complexes in the skin: This is seen in conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus, not Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • Production of autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors: This is associated with myasthenia gravis, not Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Key Takeaway: Autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid cells is the primary mechanism in Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with muscle weakness and a positive anti-acetylcholine receptor antibody test. Which autoimmune disease is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Myasthenia gravis: Characterized by the presence of anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies, leading to muscle weakness due to impaired neuromuscular transmission.
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis: Involves autoantibodies against thyroid peroxidase and does not typically present with anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies.
  • Grave's disease: Involves autoantibodies against the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor, not acetylcholine receptors.
  • Addison's disease: Involves adrenal cortex autoantibodies, not anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies.

Key Takeaway: Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies are indicative of myasthenia gravis.

choices.text: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells
Immune-mediated destruction of the thyroid gland
Defective T cell maturation in the thymus

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
• Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells: This describes Type 1 diabetes, not psoriasis.
  • Hyperproliferation of keratinocytes: Psoriasis is characterized by the rapid turnover and proliferation of skin cells (keratinocytes), leading to thickened skin and scaling.
  • Immune-mediated destruction of the thyroid gland: This is seen in Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, not psoriasis.
  • Defective T cell maturation in the thymus: This is related to autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome, not psoriasis.

Key Takeaway: Psoriasis is primarily due to the hyperproliferation of keratinocytes.

questions.text: In the context of autoimmune diseases, which laboratory test is most useful for diagnosing Sjögren's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Anti-SSA/Ro antibodies: These are commonly associated with Sjögren's syndrome and can also be seen in SLE, making them useful for diagnosing Sjögren's.
  • Anti-CCP antibodies: Specific for rheumatoid arthritis, not Sjögren's syndrome.
  • Anti-dsDNA antibodies: Specific for SLE, not Sjögren's syndrome.
  • Anti-Scl-70 antibodies: Associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), not Sjögren's syndrome.

Key Takeaway: Anti-SSA/Ro antibodies are a key marker for diagnosing Sjögren's syndrome.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism behind autoimmune diseases?
questions.solution:
• Immune system attacking self-tissues is the hallmark of autoimmune diseases, where the immune system mistakenly targets the body's own cells.
  • Overproduction or B. Underproduction of antibodies can be involved but do not define the autoimmune mechanism.
  • Deficiency of immune cells is related to immunodeficiency, not autoimmunity.

Key Takeaway: Autoimmune diseases involve the immune system erroneously attacking the body's own tissues.

choices.text: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in non-coding regions

questions.text: Which genetic factor is commonly associated with an increased risk of developing autoimmune diseases?
questions.solution:
• HLA gene variations (Human Leukocyte Antigen) are strongly associated with susceptibility to various autoimmune diseases due to their role in immune system regulation.
  • Mitochondrial DNA mutations are related to mitochondrial disorders, not specifically autoimmune diseases.
  • X-linked chromosomal abnormalities can affect various genetic conditions but are less directly linked to autoimmune diseases.
  • SNPs in non-coding regions may play a role but are not as directly associated with autoimmune risk as HLA variations.

Key Takeaway: HLA gene variations are significant genetic factors in autoimmune disease susceptibility.

questions.text: Based on the image, which MHC is primarily involved in presenting antigens to CD4+ T cells?
questions.solution:
Figure shows CD4+ T helper cells

  • MHC Class II molecules are primarily involved in presenting antigens to CD4+ T helper cells.
  • MHC Class I molecules present antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.

Key Takeaway: MHC Class II is crucial for activating CD4+ T cells.

questions.text: What does MHC stand for in immunology?
questions.solution:
• Major Histocompatibility Complex is the correct term used for molecules that present antigens to T cells.
  • B, C, D are incorrect terms and do not accurately represent the MHC.

Key Takeaway: MHC stands for Major Histocompatibility Complex.

choices.text: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells, while MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens to CD4+ T cells.
MHC class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs), whereas MHC class II molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells.
MHC class I molecules present exogenous antigens, whereas MHC class II molecules present endogenous antigens.
MHC class I molecules are involved in activating helper T cells, while MHC class II molecules are involved in activating cytotoxic T cells.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes a key difference between MHC class I and MHC class II molecules?
questions.solution:
• MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T cells, while MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens to CD4+ T cells: This is correct. MHC class I molecules present peptides from intracellular (endogenous) proteins to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, while MHC class II molecules present peptides from extracellular (exogenous) proteins to CD4+ helper T cells.
  • MHC class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs), whereas MHC class II molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells: This is incorrect. MHC class I molecules are expressed on all nucleated cells, while MHC class II molecules are restricted to professional APCs (such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells).
  • MHC class I molecules present exogenous antigens, whereas MHC class II molecules present endogenous antigens: This is incorrect. MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, while MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens.
  • MHC class I molecules are involved in activating helper T cells, while MHC class II molecules are involved in activating cytotoxic T cells: This is incorrect. MHC class I molecules activate cytotoxic T cells (CD8+), and MHC class II molecules activate helper T cells (CD4+).

Key Takeaway: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells and are expressed on all nucleated cells, whereas MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens to CD4+ helper T cells and are primarily expressed on antigen-presenting cells.

choices.text: To present antigens to T cells

questions.text: What is the primary role of the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) in the immune system?
questions.solution:
• MHC molecules are crucial for presenting antigens to T cells, enabling the immune system to recognize and respond to pathogens.
  • Producing antibodies is the role of B cells, not MHC.
  • Killing pathogens directly is not the role of MHC; it's more about antigen presentation.
  • Regulating blood pressure is unrelated to MHC function.

Key Takeaway: The MHC's primary function is to present antigens to T cells for immune recognition.

questions.text: What does "HLA" stand for in the context of MHC molecules?
questions.solution:
• Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) refers to the MHC molecules found on human leukocytes (white blood cells).
  • Lymphocyte Antigen and C. Lymphoid Antigen are incorrect terms.
  • Liver Antigen is unrelated to MHC terminology.

Key Takeaway: "HLA" stands for Human Leukocyte Antigen, which is crucial for antigen presentation.

questions.text: Which autoimmune disease is commonly associated with specific MHC Class II alleles, particularly HLA-DR4?
questions.solution:
• Rheumatoid Arthritis: The HLA-DR4 allele is strongly associated with an increased risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4 but not specifically HLA-DR4.
  • Multiple Sclerosis is associated with HLA-DR2.
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is associated with HLA-DR2 and HLA-DR3, not specifically HLA-DR4.

Key Takeaway: HLA-DR4 is notably linked to rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which MHC Class I molecule is associated with an increased risk of developing the autoimmune disease ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.solution:
• HLA-B27: This MHC Class I allele is strongly associated with an increased risk of developing ankylosing spondylitis, a type of inflammatory arthritis.
  • HLA-B35 and C. HLA-A2 are not specifically linked to ankylosing spondylitis.
  • HLA-Cw6 is associated with psoriasis, not ankylosing spondylitis.

Key Takeaway: HLA-B27 is a key genetic marker for susceptibility to ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: In the provided diagram of an MHC Class I molecule, identify the labeled part.
questions.solution:
• Peptide-Binding Groove (C): This is the region of the MHC Class I molecule where endogenous peptides are loaded and presented to CD8+ T cells.

Key Takeaway: The peptide-binding groove is crucial for presenting endogenous peptides in MHC Class I.

choices.text: Both MHC class I and MHC class II
Neither MHC class I nor MHC class II

questions.text: Which type of MHC molecule is responsible for presenting antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells?
questions.solution:
• MHC class I: This is correct. MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens (from within the cell) to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, which are responsible for killing infected or abnormal cells.
  • MHC class II: This is incorrect. MHC class II molecules present exogenous antigens (from outside the cell) to CD4+ helper T cells, not CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.
  • Both MHC class I and MHC class II: This is incorrect. Only MHC class I molecules present antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells. MHC class II molecules present to CD4+ helper T cells.
  • Neither MHC class I nor MHC class II: This is incorrect. MHC class I molecules specifically present to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.

Key Takeaway: MHC class I molecules are responsible for presenting antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, which helps in identifying and destroying infected or cancerous cells.
